## What are the foci of an ellipse?

[[☃ image 1]]

The $\maroonC{\text{foci}}$ of an ellipse are two points whose sum of distances from any point on the ellipse is always the same. They lie on the ellipse's $\greenD{\text{major radius}}$.

The distance between each focus and the center is called the **focal length** of the ellipse. The following equation relates the focal length $f$ with the major radius $p$ and the minor radius $q$:

$f^2=p^2-q^2$

*Want to learn more about the foci of an ellipse? Check out [this video](/v/foci-of-an-ellipse).*

## Finding the foci of an ellipse

Given the radii of an ellipse, we can use the equation $f^2=p^2-q^2$ to find its focal length. Then, the foci will lie on the major axis, $f$ units away from the center (in each direction). Let's find, for example, the foci of this ellipse:

[[☃ image 2]]

We can see that the major radius of our ellipse is $5$ units, and its minor radius is $4$ units.

$\begin{align}
f^2&=p^2-q^2
\\\\
f^2&=5^2-4^2
\\\\
f^2&=9
\\\\
f&=3
\end{align}$

The major axis is the horizontal one, so the foci lie $\greenD3$ units to the right and left of the center.  In other words, the foci lie at $(-4\pm\greenD 3,3)$, which are $(-7,3)$ and $(-1,3)$.

[[☃ image 3]]

hint.content:
The major radius of our ellipse is $6.5$ units, and its minor radius is $2.5$ units.

$\begin{align}
f^2&=p^2-q^2
\\\\
f^2&=6.5^2-2.5^2
\\\\
f^2&=36
\\\\
f&=6
\end{align}$

Note that the major radius corresponds to the major axis, which is vertical in this case. So the foci lie $\greenD6$ units to the top and bottom of the center. 

Therefore, the foci lie at $(5,-2\pm\greenD 6)$, which is to say $(5,4)$ and $(5,-8)$.

$\dfrac{(x+8)^2}{169}+\dfrac{(y+9)^2}{25}=1$

**What are the foci of the ellipse**?

[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
Based on the formula, the ellipse is centered at $(-8,-9)$, has a major radius of $13$, and a minor radius of $5$.

$\begin{align}
f^2&=p^2-q^2
\\\\
f^2&=13^2-5^2
\\\\
f^2&=144
\\\\
f&=12
\end{align}$

Note that the major radius corresponds to the major axis, which is horizontal in this case. So the foci lie $\greenD {12}$ units to the right and left of the center. 

Therefore, the foci lie at $(-8\pm\greenD {12},-9)$, which is to say $(-20,-9)$ and $(4,-9)$.
